block.p: Republicans Use Weight To Approve $17 Billion Cut

House Republicans used their superior numbers to cut $17 billion from the current budget. The bill would end scores of Federal programs, including summer jobs for youths, and would cut $7.3 billion from low-income housing programs. A1.
Republicans Use Weight To Approve $17 Billion Cut

House Republicans used their superior numbers to cut $17 billion from the current budget. The bill would end scores of Federal programs, including summer jobs for youths, and would cut $7.3 billion from low-income housing programs. A1.

Republicans on the House Budget Committee voted to cut $100 billion from future Federal budgets to pay for some of the tax cuts they promised in the Contract With America. A18. Conoco Told White House About Iran Deal Four Years Ago

The Administration acknowledged that Conoco had told American officials repeatedly over the last four years that it was negotiating with Iran to develop a $1 billion oilfield. A1. Slowdown Eases Inflation Fears

Retail prices climbed 0.3 percent, housing starts declined 2.6 percent and weekly claims for unemployment insurance increased, providing evidence that an economic slowdown is helping moderate inflation. D2. Nine West's Deal With U.S. Shoe

United States Shoe agreed to sell its footwear division to Nine West for $600 million, rejecting a $1.1 billion bid for the entire company from the Italian eyewear company, Luxottica. Analysts expect a battle. D3. Pfizer Increases Research Budget
Pfizer plans to spend $1.4 billion on research this year, a surge of 20 percent, which analysts said would move Pfizer past Merck in total research spending. D5. Pollution Credits Expanded

The Administration said it would allow industry to cut costs by trading smog- and water pollution credits, a novelty now mainly restricted to an acid rain pollutant. A20.. Bank to Form Annuity Sales Force
First Union of North Carolina plans to license 800 employees to sell annuities, further weakening the barriers between banks and insurance companies. D2. Orange County Seeks a Deferral

Orange County, Calif., asked its creditors to delay the repayment of $975 million of county debt due this summer until 1996 to give it time to rebuild its strained finances. D16. No Merger for Duff & Phelps
Govett and Duff & Phelps terminated their $230 million merger agreement. Analysts said Duff & Phelps was now likely to receive offers from other investment firms. D3. The Options for Viacom

Wall Street still expects Viacom to find a way to structure a sale of its cable systems without a large tax liability, although Congress appears to have blocked the company's plans to sell the systems to a minority-led group. D5. Mexico Crisis Hangs Over ING

The biggest question mark hanging over ING of the Netherlands may not be its purchase of Barings, but the effects of the Mexican peso crisis on its earnings. Market Place. D6. U.A.W. Threatened With Strike Today

Clerical and maintenance workers employed by the U.A.W at dozens of union offices around the country are threatening to strike this morning over job security and workplace quality issues. D2. Charges Against Tax Preparers

H & R Block and two other tax preparers were charged by New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs with deceptive advertising and misleading the public about their electronic filing and rapid refund services. B3. Saatchi Shareholders Get Their Say Saatchi & Saatchi shareholders voted to change the company's name to Cordiant, but not before railing about the rancorous departures of the Saatchi brothers and big account losses. Advertising. D5.
